review_title: Depends on your preference/luck, but maybe stay away if you can find a better option.
pros:
- If lucky, you get sent to outlets that are less profit driven for promotions, which allows you to establish deeper and more solid connections with customers
- training is quite active and fun
cons:
- Upper management oblivious to working conditions of staff; some people (Area Lead) can text in inappropriate and disrespectful manners by all-capsing and accusing the promoters of not doing their job despite having done so 
- Depending on outlet, promoters can be isolated from the full time staff at retail outlets; queries to client (retail) staff can be dismissed/ignored
- Micromanagement here and there, with photos taken of "inappropriate grooming and posture" without consent. No particular attempt to communicate with staff on their daily needs, only consistently texted and asked "are you aware of your role as a promoter?"
- No particular attempt to motivate or understand the promoters; only positions "consequences" and "being fierce" as a reaction to negative complaints.
- long retail hours; depending on outlet, may not even allow promoters to use toilet/sit when needed
- overall, potentially red flag for those looking for a management that respects your work rather than threatening to fire you constantly

review_title: Best recruiting firm to work for in the country!
pros: Supportive management team, that invests heavily in their teams. There is a good balance between performance goals and accountability in a way that empowers their teams to be effective. At Adecco, they specialize in Verticals i.e Manufacturing and Technology, as opposed to department segments, like accounting and finance, or marketing. At Adecco, a recruiter can work any position from an entry level operator all the way to an executive position. That means each company only has one point of contact which our clients prefer. Also, we are not stuck only in regions, so although I'm based in Orange County, If I client has a role in another state, I can not only work it, but also bring on the team in that city to help. This has made it much more lucrative to work at Adecco than at other recruiting firms. Lastly, the fees are the most competitive. They offer a Draw plan, that pays a commission of 40,50 & 60% or a salary plan that pays at 10,15, or 20%. In addition, managers also get a generous override as well.
cons: It's like a billion-dollar start-up, because Search is new. The team has scaled over 200% in the last 2 years, so they are still building out some of the foundational tools needed. Regardless this has not hindered my ability to make great money in a supportive team

pros: Flexibility, positive coworkers, ability to work from home
cons: Lack of stability - several rounds of layoffs in the 1.5 years I was there. Senior leaders are not strategic in decision making. Sales team does not target competitive business and business is not diversified. Senior leaders are hostile and rude to employees and high degree of unprofessionalism between field teams and corporate roles. Lack of accountability for senior leaders. KPIs changed several times during a review cycle without explanation. The company had no consistent way to track bonuses and commissions and employees have no transparency into the programs or how it was calculated. Were just told that KPIs were not met. My manager lacked basic leadership skills in terms of communication. Change is managed poorly or not at all. Do not accept a position here. You will most likely be laid off.

pros: The work itself is crushingly dull but it's pretty informal and you can interact or not with your coworkers and everyone is nice enough.
cons: Great Benefits is a giant lie. If you need health insurance from your job, and you will since you will earn too much to keep Medicaid and not enough for any kind of useful insurance, then this is not the job for you. But if your $17/h is for extras, like cruises, then this is the job for you since they consider cruise discounts to be yet another Great Benefit. But hey, no pto for that discount cruise. This is a job to do between jobs, not an actual job.

pros:
I worked specifically in the Adecco Search (Full-time hires / Direct Hire) team, so my experience is likely pretty different from many folks in the much larger Temp / Staffing area of Adecco. With that said...

—My team was wonderful. Supportive, communicative, and always pushing each other to succeed & try harder without being overbearing or applying too much pressure.
— My manager especially was outstanding. She was a real pro and was very supportive and hands on while still running a very busy desk herself.
— PTO policy was pretty generous (about 22 days a year if I recall correctly) and accommodations were always reasonably flexible
cons:
—Because it's such a large company, any decisions or teams outside of my immediate team I felt extremely disconnected with.
— Upper level leadership is extremely inaccessible and out of touch with the reality of what most employees work with day to day
— Many of our clients clearly viewed us as "necessary evils" vs legitimate, consultative partners, and were very rude and short in their interactions with myself and my team.
— The job, like at any recruiting agency, is a grind. You have to WANT IT and really be willing to hustle and consistently work 50-60 hours a week if you want to succeed.

pros: Loved my team. Fully remote. Provide laptop and extra screen if needed.
cons:
Terrible organization. They were not upfront about their commission schemes at hiring; their 2021 hires were brought in on a different commission structure than their previous employees. It’s impossible to make money here unless you’ve got a strong market for temp hires. Oh and they lowballed my salary at $50k to start but other people started at almost $60k, with the same education and experience.

The technology never works. There’s a new issue every day. They reorganize teams constantly. The training threw so much info at us but most of it was not relevant for the legal industry, however there was so much more that should have been covered that we had to learn through our teams. 

Dishonesty, micromanaging, terrible commission, super corporate sales- they want you to work impossible hours but you aren’t being compensated fairly. It took me 8 months to find that out. I left to go to another company that was transparent from the very first conversation and paid their employees fairly without requiring salary negotiation

job_title: Specialty Recruiter in New York, NY
pros: Good culture. Coworkers are always happy to help each other. Job security. Benefits are inexpensive.
cons: I worked in the Medical and Science division for just under two years. During COVID, the team was thriving due to a high volume of roles, but by the time I left, there were less and less viable, lucrative opportunities. High performers have been leaving in droves. New hires were not due to expansion, but instead to fill in gaps. Management tells everyone how much the high performers make in commission, but this does NOT represent the majority. Salaries aren't great and raises are few and far between.

pros:
Its quite chaotic on the management side, but that asides the work is quite alright. However there are rooms for improvement needed on the system, it is merely a kpi tracker for the current system, and the improvement PIC refused to listen to feedbacks - even if taken also she will try to taichi it away. That being said, the ATS in the company is quite bad and is honestly JUST A KPI TRACKER SYSTEM. 

The culture is not too bad, people can be quite close knitted if you're in the same office (there are front, middle and back office). All these offices are not too interconnected and sometimes there might be some misunderstandings in between, causing employees left in rage/dissatisfaction. 

Benefits are pretty standard. MNC style. 

Verdict - 6/10, especially if you're looking to make money (comm structure is so far the best in the industry). But the management is quite chaotic, improvements are also pretty hard to execute with layers of people in between.

review_title: Terrible Benefits, Treated Like a Number and a Personal Secretary
job_title: Project Manager in Mountain View, CA
pros:
Weekly pay
Direct deposit
Full-time even when the work wasn't there daily
cons:
I worked remotely on a contract for the largest search engine company, and it wasn't a good experience. I decided to end my year contract after only a few months.

Employee onboarding takes forever! It is a long and unorganized process. I was passed around to so many different people at Adecco; it was ridiculous! My final point of contact at Adecco was rude and never answered questions. 

As an employee of Adecco, I felt like a number (employee #4,567). The benefits at Adecco are terrible. You have to work 1,000 hours or six months to receive holiday pay, zero PTO benefits, and the sick pay is accrued very slowly over time. I was there for three months (40 hrs per week) and only accrued 14 hours of sick leave. 

I'm unsure about the health and other medical benefits since I didn't sign up. I shared my benefits with my point of contact for the project, and she was shocked. I'm sure the pay is low compared to what they are paying Adecco. I had two different job titles (project manager and program manager), so I'm unsure which is correct. 

I worked with a team at the largest search engine, and I felt like a personal secretary to my point of contact there. I was spoon-fed my work, and some days I didn't have anything to do. My point of contact for the project was always stressed, and everything was always URGENT. She seemed overworked and always in meetings. She never had time for me, including training. She worked late nights and weekends all the time. One of the reasons I decided to find another role was that her work style and management style were unhealthy and toxic, and her communication was poor. 

Another thing is I didn't get credit for any of the work I had done; sometimes, my work was changed by my point of contact and presented to the team as if she had done the work. Sometimes I was in meetings and wasn't acknowledged by the other team members. The microaggressions were atroucisous.

The role was probably more fitting for someone fresh out of high school or college without much work experience. I would never work for either company again!

review_title: Decent pay for a tedious job
pros: £10.50 an hour was more than any other nearby warehouse jobs. My line manager was nice to me and usually understanding when I was late or wanted to take time off. If you're from Eastern Europe, there are many others there like you so you can easily make new friends and connections. Good overtime pay.
cons: Working in a warehouse is incredibly boring and repetetive. After about 2 weeks you can do everything on auto-pilot (might be a pro as well as a con). The hours are long (10 hours) and you will have to do weekends. They provide breakfast and lunch, but it was overpriced for the low quality food given. If you make a few mistakes or aren't scanning at a fast enough rate, you will get a 'talking to' from a guy with an iPad who you've never met. If your performance doesn't improve then you may get fired. The music they played was the same crappy radio station everyday, and you were not allowed headphones or your own phones inside the warehouse.
